column2: What is this body but a passage for the ceaseless inhaling and breathing out of the vital air? Its eyes are as two windows which are continually oped and closed by the eyelids. I do not like such a mansion as this.

column1: jihvāmarkaṭikākrāntavadanadvārabhīṣaṇam / dṛṣṭadantāsthiśakalaṃ neṣṭaṃ dehagṛha mama //
column2: This mansion of the body with its formidable (wide-open) door of the mouth, and (ever-moving) bolt of the tongue and bars of the teeth, is not pleasant to me.

column1: tvaksudhālepamasṛṇaṃ yantrasaṃcāracañcalam / manaḥ sadākhunotkhātaṃ neṣṭaṃ dehagṛhaṃ mama //
column2: This house of the body, having the white-wash of ointments on the outer skin, and the machinery of the limbs in continued motion, and the restless mind burrowing its base like the mischievous mouse, is not liked by me.

column1: smitadīpaprabhodbhāsi kṣaṇamānandasundaram / kṣaṇaṃ vyāptaṃ tamaḥpūrairneṣṭaṃ dehagṛhaṃ mama //
column2: Sweet smiles like shining lamps, serve to lighten this house of the body for a moment, but it is soon darkened by a cloud of melancholy, wherefore I cannot be pleased with it.

column1: samastarogāyatanaṃ valīpalitapattanam / sarvādhisāragahanaṃ neṣṭaṃ dehagṛhaṃ mama //
column2: This body which is the abode of diseases, and subject to wrinkles and decay, and all kinds of pain, is a mansion wherewith I am not pleased.

column1: akṣarkṣakṣobhaviṣamā śūnyā niḥsārakoṭarā / tamogahanadikkuñjā neṣṭā dehāṭavī mama //
column2: I do not like this wilderness of the body, which is infested by the bears of the senses. It is empty and hollow within, with dark groves (of entrails) in the inside.

column1: dehālayaṃ dhārayituṃ na śaknomi munīśvara / paṅkamagnaṃ samuddhartuṃ gajamalpabalo yathā //
column2: I am unable, O chief of sages! to drag my domicile of the body, just as a weak elephant is incapable to draw out another immerged in a muddy pit.

column1: kiṃ śriyā kiṃ ca rājyena kiṃ kāyena kimīhitaiḥ / dinaiḥ katipayaireva kālaḥ sarvaṃ nikṛntati //
column2: Of what good is affluence or royalty, this body and all its efforts to one, when the hand of time must destroy them all in a few days.

column1: raktamāṃsamayasyāsya sabāhyābhyantaraṃ mune / nāśaikadharmiṇo brūhi kaiva kāyasya ramyatā //
column2: Tell me, O sage! what is charming in this body, that is only a composition of flesh and blood both within and without it and frail in its nature.

column1: maraṇāvasare kāyā jīvaṃ nānusaranti ye / teṣu tāta kṛtaghneṣu kaivāsthā vada dhīmatām //
column2: The body does not follow the soul upon death; tell me Sir, what regard should the learned have for such an ungrateful thing as this.

column1: mattebhakarṇāgracalaḥ kāyo lambāmbubhaṅguraḥ / na saṃtyajati māṃ yāvattāvadenaṃ tyajāmyaham //
column2: It is as unsteady as the ears of an infuriate elephant, and as fickle as drops of water that trickle on their tips. I should like therefore to abandon it, before it comes to abandon me.

column1: pavanaspandataralaḥ pelavaḥ kāyapallavaḥ / jarjarastanuvṛttaśca neṣṭo me kaṭunīrasaḥ //
column2: It is as tremulous as the leaves of a tree shaken by the breeze, and oppressed by diseases and fluctuations of pleasure and pain. I have no relish in its pungency and bitterness.

column1: bhuktvā pītvā ciraṃ kālaṃ bālapallavapelavām / tanutāmetya yatnena vināśamanudhāvati //
column2: With all its food and drink for evermore, it is as tender as a leaflet and is reduced to leanness in spite of all our cares, and runs fast towards its dissolution.

column1: tānyeva sukhaduḥkhāni bhāvābhāvamayānyasau / bhūyo'pyanubhavankāyaḥ prākṛto hi na lajjate //
column2: It is repeatedly subjected to pleasure and pain, and to the succession of affluence and destitution, without being ashamed of itself as the shameless vulgar herd.

column1: suciraṃ prabhutāṃ kṛtvā saṃsevya vibhavaśriyam / nocchrāyameti na sthairyaṃ kāyaḥ kimiti pālyate //
column2: Why nourish this body any longer, when it acquires no excellence nor durability of its state, after its enjoyment of prosperity and exercise of authority for a length of time.

column1: jarākāle jarāmeti mṛtyukāle tathā mṛtim / sama evāviśeṣajñaḥ kāyo bhogidaridrayoḥ //
column2: The bodies of the rich as well as those of the poor, are alike subject to decay and death at their appointed times.

column1: saṃsārāmbhodhijaṭhare tṛṣṇākuharakāntare / suptastiṣṭhati mukteho mūko'yaṃ kāyakacchapaḥ //
column2: The body lies as a tortoise in the cave of avarice amidst the ocean of the world. It remains there in the mud in a mute and torpid state, without an effort for its liberation.

column1: dahanaikārthayogyāni kāyakāṣṭhāni bhūriśaḥ / saṃsārābdhāvihohyante kaṃcitteṣu naraṃ viduḥ //
column2: Our bodies floating as heaps of wood on the waves of the world, serve at last for the fuel of funeral fire (on the pile); except a few of these which pass for human bodies in the sight of the wise.

column1: dīrghadaurātmyavalayā nipātaphalapātayā / na dehalatayā kāryaṃ kiṃcidasti vivekinaḥ //
column2: The wise have little to do with this tree of the body, which is beset by evils like noxious orchids about it, and produces the fruit of perdition.

column1: majjankardamakośeṣu jhaṭityeva jarāṃ gataḥ / na jñāyate yātyacirātkaḥ kathaṃ dehadarduraḥ //
column2: The body like a frog, lies merged in the mire of mortality, where it perishes no sooner it is known to have lived and gone.

column1: niḥsārasakalārambhāḥ kāyāścapalavāyavaḥ / rajomārgeṇa gacchanto dṛśyante neha kenacit //
column2: Our bodies are as empty and fleeting as gusts of wind, passing over a dusty ground, where nobody knows whence they come, and whither they go.

column1: vāyordīpasya manaso gacchato jñāyate gatiḥ / āgacchataśca bhagavañcharīrasya kadācana //
column2: We know not the course of our bodies (their transmigrations), as we do not know those of the winds, light and our thoughts; they all come and go, but from where and whither, we know nothing of.

column1: baddhāsthā ye śarīreṣu baddhāsthā ye jagatsthitau / tānmohamadironmattāndhigdhigastu punaḥpunaḥ //
column2: Fie and shame to them, that are so giddy with the ebriety of their error, as to rely on any state or durability of their bodies.

column1: nāhaṃ dehasya no deho mama nāyamahaṃ tathā / iti viśrāntacittā ye te mune puruṣottamāḥ //
column2: They are the best of men, O sage! whose minds are at rest with the thought, that their ego does not subsist in their bodies, nor are the bodies theirs at the end.

column1: mānāvamānabahulā bahulābhamanoramāḥ / śarīramātrabaddhāsthaṃ ghnanti doṣadṛśo naram //
column2: Those mistaken men that have a high sense of honor and fear dishonor, and take a pleasure in the excess of their gains, are verily the killers both of their bodies and souls.

column1: śarīraśvabhraśāyinyā piśācyā peśalāṅgayā / ahaṃkāracamatkṛtyā chalena chalitā vayam //
column2: We are deceived by the delusion of egoism, which like a female fiend (sorceress) lies hid within the cavity of the body with all her sorcery.

column1: prajñā varākā sarvaiva kāyabaddhāsthayānayā / mithyājñānakurākṣasyā chalitā kaṣṭamekikā //
column2: Our reason unaided (by religion) is kept in bondage like a female slave within the prison of our bodies, by the malicious fiend of false knowledge.

column1: na kiṃcidapi dṛśye'sminsatyaṃ tena hatātmanā / citraṃ dagdhaśarīreṇa janatā vipralabhyate //
column2: It is certain that whatever we see here is unreal, and yet it is a wonder, that the mass of men are led to deception by the vile body, which has injured the cause of the soul.

column1: dinaiḥ katipayaireva nirjharāmbukaṇo yathā / patatyayamayatnena jaraṭhaḥ kāyapallavaḥ //
column2: Our bodies are as fleeting as the drops of a water-fall, and they fall off in a few days like the withered leaves of trees.

column1: kāyo'yamacirāpāyo budbudo'mbunidhāviva / vyarthaṃ kāryaparāvarte parisphurati niṣphalaḥ //
column2: They are as quickly dissolved as bubbles in the ocean; it is in vain therefore that it should hurl about in the whirlpool of business.

column1: mithyājñānavikāre'sminsvapnasaṃbhramapattane / kāye sphuṭatarāpāye kṣaṇamāsthā na me dvija //
column2: I have not a moment's reliance in this body, which is ever hastening to decay;and I regard its changeful delusions as a state of dreaming.

column1: taḍitsu śaradabhreṣu gandharvanagareṣu ca / sthairyaṃ yena vinirṇītaṃ sa viśvasitu vigrahe //
column2: Let those who have any faith in the stability of the lightning, of the autumn clouds, and in glacial castles, place their reliance in this body.

column1: satatabhaṅgurakāryaparamparā vijayijātajayaṃ haṭhavṛttiṣu / prabaladoṣamidaṃ tu kalevaraṃ tṛṇamivāhamapohya sukhaṃ sthitaḥ //
column2: It has outdone all other things that are doomed to destruction in its instability and perishableness. It is moreover subject to very many evils; wherefore I have set it at naught as a straw, and thereby obtained my repose.

column1: śrīrāma uvāca / labdhvāpi taralākāre kāryabhārataraṃgiṇi / saṃsārasāgare janma bālyaṃ duḥkhāya kevalam //
column2: One receiving his birth in the unstable ocean of the world, which is disturbed by the billows of the bustle of business, has to pass his boyhood in sufferings only.

column1: aśaktirāpadastṛṣṇā mūkatā mūḍhabuddhitā / gṛdhnutā lolatā dainyaṃ sarvaṃ bālye pravartate //
column2: Want of strength and sense, and subjection to diseases and dangers, muteness and appetence, joined with longings and helplessness, are the concomitants of infancy.

column1: roṣarodanaraudrāsu dainyajarjaritāsu ca / daśāsu bandhanaṃ bālyamālānaṃ kariṇāmiva //
column2: Childhood is chained to fretting and crying, to fits of anger, craving and every kind of incapacity, as an elephant when tied to the post by its shackles.

column1: na mṛtau na jarāroge na cāpadi na yauvane / tāścintāḥ parikṛntanti hṛdayaṃ śaiśaveṣu yāḥ //
column2: The vexations which tease the infant breast, are far greater than those which trouble us in youth and old age, or disturb one in disease, danger or at the approach of death.

column1: tiryagjātisamārambhaḥ sarvairevāvadhīritaḥ / lolo bālasamācāro maraṇādapi duḥkhadaḥ //
column2: The acts of a boy are as those of young animals, that are always restless and snubbed by every body. Hence boyhood is more intolerable than death itself.

column1: pratibimbaghanājñānaṃ nānāsaṃkalpapelavam / bālyamālūnasaṃśīrṇamanaḥ kasya sukhāvaham //
column2: How can boyhood be pleasing to any body, when it is but a semblance of gross ignorance, and full of whims and hobbies, and ever subject to miscarriages.

column1: jalavahnayanilājasrajātabhītyā pade pade / yadbhayaṃ śaiśave'buddhyā kasyāpadi hi tadbhavet //
column2: It is this silly boyhood which is in constant dread of dangers arising at every step from fire, water and air, and which rarely betide us in other states of life.

column1: līlāsu durvilāseṣu durīhāsu durāśaye / paramaṃ mohamādhatte bālo balavadāpatan //
column2: Boys are liable to very many errors in their plays and wicked frolics, and in all their wishes and attempts beyond their capacities:hence boyhood is the most perilous state.

column1: vikalpakalpitārambhaṃ durvilārasaṃ durāspadam / śaiśavaṃ śāsanāyaiva puruṣasya na śāntaye //
column2: Boys are engaged in false pursuits and wicked sports, and are subject to all foolish puerilities. Hence boyhood is fit for the rod and not for rest.

column1: ye doṣā ye durācārā duṣkramā ye durādhayaḥ / te sarve saṃsthitā bālye durgarta iva kauśikāḥ //
column2: All faults, misconduct, transgressions and heart-aches, lie hidden in boyhood like owls in hollow caves.

column1: bālyaṃ ramyamiti vyarthabuddhayaḥ kalpayanti ye / tānmūrkhapuruṣānbrahmandhigastu hṛtacetasaḥ //
column2: Fie to those ignorant and foolish people, who are falsely led to imagine boyhood as the most pleasant period of life.

column1: yatra dolākṛti manaḥ parisphurati vṛttiṣu / trailokyā'bhavyamapi tatkathaṃ bhavati tuṣṭaye //
column2: How can boyhood appear pleasing to any one, when the mind swings like a cradle towards every object of desire, however wrong it is deemed to be in both worlds.

column1: sarveṣāmeva sattvānāṃ sarvāvasthābhya eva hi / manaścañcalatāmeti bālye daśaguṇaṃ mune //
column2: The minds of all living beings are ever restless, but those of young people are ten times more at unrest.

column1: manaḥ prakṛtyaiva calaṃ bālyaṃ ca calatāṃ varam / tayoḥ saṃśliṣyatostrātā ka ivāntaḥ kucāpale //
column2: The mind is naturally unsteady, and so is boyhood also. Say what can save us from that state of life, when both these vagrant things combine to our destruction.

column1: strīlocanaistaḍitpuñjairjvalājālaistaraṅgakaiḥ / cāpalaṃ śikṣitaṃ brahmañchaiśavākrāntacetasaḥ //
column2: The glances of women, the flashes of lightning, the flame of fire, and the ever-rolling waves, have all imitated the fickleness of boyhood.

column1: śaiśavaṃ ca manaścaiva sarvāsveva hi vṛttiṣu / bhrātarāviva lakṣyete satataṃ bhaṅgurasthitī //
column2: Minority seems to be a twin brother to the mind, and resembles it in the unsteadiness and frailty of all its purposes.

column1: sarvāṇi duḥkhabhūtāni sarve doṣā durādhayaḥ / bālamevopajīvanti śrīmantamiva mānavāḥ //
column2: All kinds of miseries, misdeeds and miscarriages await on boyhood, as all sorts of men hang upon the rich.

column1: navaṃ navaṃ prītikaraṃ na śiśuḥ pratyahaṃ yadi / prāpnoti tadasau yāti viṣavaiṣamyamūrcchanām //
column2: Boys are fond of fresh things at all times, and on their failing to get the same, they fall to a fainting fit, as if from the effect of poison.

column1: stokena vaśamāyāti stokenaiti vikāritām / amedhya eva ramate bālaḥ kauleyako yathā //
column2: A boy like a dog, is as easily tamed as he is irritated at a little, and he is as glad to lie in the dust, as to play with dirt.

column1: ajasravāṣpavadanaḥ kardamākto jaḍāśayaḥ / varṣokṣitasya taptasya sthalasya sadṛśaḥ śiśuḥ //
column2: A foolish fretful boy with his body daubed in mire with the tears in his eyes, appears as a heap of dry clay soiled by a shower of rain.

column1: bhayāhāraparaṃ dīnaṃ dṛṣṭādṛṣṭābhilāṣi ca / lolabuddhi vapurdhatte bālyaṃ duḥkhāya kevalam //
column2: Boys are subject to fear and voracity; they are helpless but fond of every thing they have seen or heard, and equally fickle in their bodies and mind. Hence boyhood is a source of troubles only.

column1: svasaṃkalpābhilaṣitānbhāvānaprāpya taptadhīḥ / duḥkhametyabalo bālo viniṣkṛtta ivāśaye //
column2: The foolish and helpless child, becomes as sad and sour when he fails to get the object of his fancy, as when he is thwarted from the thing desired.

column1: durīhālabdhalakṣāṇi bahuvakrolbaṇāni ca / bālasya yāni duḥkhāni mune tāni na kasyacit //
column2: Children have much difficulty to get at the things they want, and which they can ask only by indistinct words. Hence no one suffers so much as boys.

column1: bālo balavatā svena manorathavilāsinā / manasā tapyate nityaṃ grīṣmeṇeva vanasthalī //
column2: A boy is as much irritated by the eagerness of his whimsical desires, as a patch of ground in the desert is parched by the summer heat.

column1: vidyāgṛhagato bālo parāmeti kadarthanām / ālāna iva nāgendro viṣavaiṣamyabhīṣaṇām //
column2: A boy on entering his school, is subjected to corrections, which are as painful to him as the goading and fetters to the elephant.

column1: nānāmanorathamayī mithyākalpitakalpanā / duḥkhāyātyantadīrghāya bālatā pelavāśayā //
column2: A great many whims and hobbies, and a variety of false fancies, tend continually to afflict boyhood, which is ever fond of toys and trifles.

column1: saṃhṛṣṭo bhuvanaṃ bhoktamindumādātumambarāt / vāñchate yena maurkhyeṇa tatsukhāya kathaṃ bhavet //
column2: How can senseless childhood be said to be a happy state of life, when the child is led by its ignorance to swallow everything in the world, and to wish to lay hold on the moon in the sky.

column1: antaścitteraśaktasya śītātapanivāraṇe / ko viśeṣo mahābuddhe bālasyorvīruhastathā //
column2: Say great sage! what difference is there between a child and a tree, both of which have sensitiveness, but unable to defend themselves from heat and cold.

column1: uḍḍītumabhivāñchanti pakṣābhyāṃ kṣutparāyaṇāḥ / bhayāhāraparā nityaṃ bālā vihagadharmiṇaḥ //
column2: Boys are of the nature of birds, being both subject to fear and hunger, and ready to fly about when impelled by them.

column1: śaiśave guruto bhītirmātṛtaḥ pitṛtastathā / janato jyeṣṭhabālācca śaiśavaṃ bhayamandiram //
column2: Again boyhood is the abode of fear from all sides; such as from the tutor, father, mother, elder brother and elderly boys, and from every body besides.

column1: sakaladoṣadaśāvihatāśayaṃ śaraṇamapyavivekavilāsinaḥ / iha na kasyacideva mahāmune bhavati bālyamalaṃ parituṣṭaye //
column2: Hence the hopeless state of childhood, which is full of faults and errors, and addicted to sports and thoughtlessness, cannot be satisfactory to any body.

column1: śrīrāma uvāca / bālyānarthamatha tyaktvā pumānabhihatāśayaḥ / ārohati nipātāya yauvanaṃ saṃbhrameṇa tu //
column2: Rama continued:—The boy having passed his state of blemishes, gladly steps to his youth with hopes of gaining his objects that tend only to his ruin.

column1: tatrānantavilāsasya lolasya svasya cetasaḥ / vṛttīranubhavanyāti duḥkhādduḥkhāntaraṃ jaḍaḥ //
column2: The insensible youth feels at this time the wanton inclinations of his loose mind, and goes on falling from one tribulation to another.

column1: svacittabilasaṃsthena nānāsaṃbhramakāriṇā / balātkāmapiśācena vivaśaḥ paribhūyate //
column2: He is overcome as one subdued by the power of delusive cupid, lying hidden in the cavity of the heart.

column1: cintānāṃ lolavṛttīnāṃ lalanānāmivā'vṛtīḥ / arpayatyavaśaṃ ceto bālānāmañjanaṃ yathā //
column2: His ungoverned mind gives rise to loose thoughts like those of voluptuous women, and these serve to beguile him like the magic collyrium (in the hand) of boys.

column1: te te doṣā durārambhāstatra taṃ tādṛśāśayam / tadrūpaṃ pratilumpanti duṣṭāstenaiva ye mune //
column2: Vices of the most heinous kind betake persons of such (perverse) minds in their youth, and lead them to their ruin.

column1: mahānarakabījena saṃtatabhramadāyinā / yauvanena na ye naṣṭā naṣṭā nānyena te janāḥ //
column2: The paths of youth lead them to the gate of hell through a maze of errors. Those that have been left uncorrupt by their youth, are not to be corrupted by anything else.

column1: nānārasamayī citravṛttāntanicayombhitā / bhīmā yauvanabhūryena tīrṇā dhīraḥ sa ucyate //
column2: Whoso has passed the dreadfully enchanted coast of youth, fraught with various flavours and wonders, are said to be truly wise.

column1: nimeṣabhāsurākāramālolaghanagarjitam / vidyutprakāśamaśivaṃ yauvanaṃ me na rocate //
column2: I take no delight in our unwelcome youth, which appears to us in the form of a momentary flash of lightning, and soon succeeded by the loud roaring of the clouds.

column1: madhuraṃ svādu tiktaṃ ca dūṣaṇaṃ doṣabhūṣaṇam / surākallolasadṛśaṃ yauvanaṃ me na rocate //
column2: Youth like rich wine is sweet and delicious (at first), but becomes bitter, insipid and noxious in a short time. Hence it is not delectable to me.

column1: asatyaṃ satyasaṃkāśamacirādvipralambhadam / svapnāṅganāsaṅgasamaṃ yauvanaṃ me na rocate //
column2: Youth appearing (at first) as a reality, is found to be a false, transient thing, as deceptive as a fairy dream by night. Hence I like it not.

column1: sarvasyāgre sarvapuṃsaḥ kṣaṇamātramanoharam / gandharvanagaraprakhyaṃ yauvanaṃ me na rocate //
column2: It is the most charming of all things to men, but its charm is soon lost and fled. Therefore the phantasmagoria of youth is not pleasing to me.

column1: iṣuprapātamātraṃ hi sukhadaṃ duḥkhabhāsuram / dāhapoṣapradaṃ nityaṃ yauvanaṃ me na rocate //
column2: Youth as an arrow shot is pleasant to see, but painful to feel its smart. Hence I do not like youth that produces blood heat.

column1: āpātamātraramaṇaṃ sadbhāvarahitāntaram / veśyāstrīsaṃgamaprakhyaṃ yauvanaṃ me na rocate //
column2: Youth as a harlot is charming at first sight, but turning heartless soon after. Hence it is not to my liking.

column1: ye kecana samārambhāste sarve sarvaduḥkhadāḥ / tāruṇye saṃnidhiṃ yānti mahotpātā iva kṣaye //
column2: As the efforts of a dying man are all for his torment, so the exertions of the young are portentous of his destruction.

column1: hārdāndhakārakāriṇyā bhairavākāravānapi / yauvanājñānayāminyā bibheti bhagavānapi //
column2: Puberty advances as a dark night spreading the shadow of destruction. It darkens the heart and mind by its hedious appearance, and intimidates even the god.

column1: suvismṛtaśubhācāraṃ buddhivaidhuryadāyinam / dadātyatitarāmeṣa bhramaṃ yauvanasaṃbhramaḥ //
column2: Errors growing in youth, cause copious mistakes in life, by upsetting good sense and setting at naught the approved good manners.

column1: kāntāviyogajātena hṛdi duḥsparśavahninā / yauvane dahyate jantustarurdāvāgninā yathā //
column2: The raging fire in the hearts of the young, caused by separation of their mates, burns them down like trees by a wild fire.

column1: sunirmalāpi vistīrṇā pāvanyapi hi yauvane / matiḥ kaluṣatāmeti prāvṛṣīva taraṅgiṇī //
column2: As a clear, sacred and wide stream, becomes muddy in the rains, so doth the mind of man however clear, pure and expanded it may be, gets polluted in his youth.

column1: śakyate ghanakallolā bhīmā laṅghayituṃ nadī / na tu tāruṇyataralā tṛṣṇātaralitāntarā //
column2: It is possible for one to cross over a river made terrible by its waves, but no way possible to him to get over the boisterous expanse of his youthful desires.

column1: sā kāntā tau stanau pīnau te vilāsāstadānanam / tāruṇya iti cintābhiryāti jarjaratāṃ janaḥ //

column2: As the Ganges upsets a neighbouring tree by its rapid course, so does old age destroy the body, as the current of our life runs fast to decay.

column2: Old age which preys on the flesh of the human body, takes as much delight in devouring its youthful bloom as a cat does in feeding upon a mouse.

column2: The body like a flowering creeper, bends down under the pressure of age, turns to grey like the fading leaves of a plant, and becomes as lean and thin as a plant after its flowering time is over.

column2: As the infuriate elephant upsets the white plantain tree in a moment, so does old age destroy the body that becomes as white as camphor all over.

column2: Old age like a juggling girl, struts on three legs at the sound of coughing and whiffing, beating as a tymbal on both sides.

column2: The tuft of grey hairs on the head of the aged body, represents a white flapper (chowry) fastened to the top of a handle of white sandal wood, to welcome the despot of death.

column2: As hoary age makes his advance like moon-light on the site of the body, he calls forth the hidden death to come out of it, as the moon-light makes the nilumbium to unfold its buds.

column2: Again as the white wash of old age whitens the outer body, so debility, diseases and dangers become its inmates in the inner typo apartment.

column2: Good people can have no more confidence in the net work of their ribs, than little children may have a liking for fruits reflected in a mirror.

column1: śubhāśubhaviṣāṇāgravilūnajanapallavaḥ / sphūrjati sphītajanatājīvarājīvanīgajaḥ //
column2: Time like a wild elephant uproots all proud living beings in this world, as the other pulls up the trees of the forest with their tusks.

column2: This creation of God is like a forest, having Brahma for its foundation and its trees full of the great fruits of gods. Time commands it throughout its length and breadth.

column1: śrīrāma uvāca / iti me doṣadāvāgnidagdhe mahati cetasi / prasphuranti na bhogāśā mṛgatṛṣṇāḥ saraḥsviva //
column2: Thus is my heart consumed by the wild-fire of those great worldly evils, and there rises in me no desire of enjoying them, as there rises no mirage from a lake.

column1: pratyahaṃ yāti kaṭutāmeṣā saṃsārasaṃsthitiḥ / kālapākavaśāllolā rasā nimbalatā yathā //
column2: My existence upon earth gets bitter day by day, and though I have got some experience in it, yet its associations have made me as sour as the Nimba plant by its immersion in water.

column1: vṛddhimāyāti daurjanyaṃ saujanyaṃ yāti tānavam / karañjakarkaśe rājanpratyahaṃ janacetasi //
column2: I see wickedness on the increase, and righteousness on the decline in the mind of man, which like the sour Karanja (crab) fruit, becomes sourer every day.

column1: bhajyate bhuvi maryādā jhaṭityeva dinaṃ prati / śuṣkeva māṣaśimbīkā ṭaṅkārakaravaṃ vinā //
column2: I see honour is eaten up every day by mutual altercations of men, using harsh words to each other as they crack the nuts under their teeth.

column1: rājyebhyo bhogapūgebhyaścintāvadbhyo munīśvara / nirastacintākalitā varamekāntaśīlatā //
column2: Too much eagerness for royalty and worldly enjoyments, is equally prejudicial to our welfare; as we loose our future prospects by the former, and our present happiness by the latter.

column1: nānandāya mamodyānaṃ na sukhāya mama striyaḥ / na harṣāya mamārthāśā śāmyāmi manasā saha //
column2: I take no delight in my gardens nor have any pleasure in women; I feel no joy at the prospect of riches, but enjoy my solace in my own heart and mind.

column1: anityaścāsukho lokastṛṣṇā tāta durudvahā / cāpalopahataṃ cetaḥ kathaṃ yāsyāmi nirvṛtim //
column2: Frail are the pleasures of the world, and avarice is altogether intolerable; the bustle of business has broken down my heart, and (I know not) where to have my tranquility.

column1: nābhinandāmi maraṇaṃ nābhinandāmi jīvitam / yathā tiṣṭhāmi tiṣṭhāmi tathaiva vigatajvaram //
column2: Neither do I hail death nor am I in love with my life; but remain as I do, devoid of all anxiety and care.

column1: kiṃ me rājyena kiṃ bhogaiḥ kimarthena kimīhitaiḥ / ahaṃkāravaśādetatsa eva galito mama //
column2: What have I to do with a kingdom and with all its enjoyments? Of what avail are riches to me, and what is the end of all our exertions? All these are but requirements of self-love, from which I am entirely free.

column1: janmāvalivaratrāyāmindriyagranthayo dṛḍhāḥ / ye baddhāstadvimokṣārthaṃ yatante ye ta uttamāḥ //
column2: The chain of (repeated) births is a bond that binds fast all men by its strong knots of the senses; those striving to break loose from this bondage for their liberation, are (said to be) the best of men.

column1: mathitaṃ māninīlokairmano makaraketunā / komalaṃ khuraniṣpeṣaiḥ kamalaṃ kariṇā yathā //
column2: These haughty damsels whom the god of love employs to ravage the hearts of men, resemble a group of elephants subverting a lotus bed under their feet.

column1: adya cetsvacchayā buddhyā munīndra na cikitsyate / bhūyaścittacikitsāyāstatkilāvasaraḥ kutaḥ //
column2: The treatment of the mind with pure reason being neglected now (in youth), it is hard to heal it afterwards (in age), when it admits of no cure.

column1: viṣaṃ viṣayavaiṣamyaṃ na viṣaṃ viṣamucyate / janmāntaraghnā viṣayā ekadehaharaṃ viṣam //
column2: It is the worldliness of man that is his true poison, while real poison is no poison to him. It is the poison of worldliness which destroys his future life, while real poison is only locally injurious to him.

column1: na sukhāni na duḥkhāni na mitrāṇi na bāndhavāḥ / na jīvitaṃ na maraṇaṃ bandhāya jñasya cetasaḥ //
column2: Neither pleasure nor pain, nor friends nor relatives, nor even life and death, can enchain (affect) the mind that has received the light of truth.

column1: tadbhavāmi yathā brahmanpūrvāparavidāṃ vara / vītaśokabhayāyāso jñastathopadiśāśu me //
column2: Teach me, Oh Brahman! that art the best of the learned in the mysteries of the past and future, teach me so that I may soon become like one devoid of grief and fear and worldly troubles, and may have the light of truth beaming upon me.

column1: vāsanājālavalitā duḥkhakaṇṭakasaṃkulā / nipātotpātabahulā bhīmarūpā'jñatāṭavī //
column2: The forest of ignorance is laid over with the snare of desire, it is full of the thorns of misery, and is the dreadful seat of destruction and the danger.

column1: krakacāgraviniṣpeṣaṃ soḍhuṃ śaknomyahaṃ mune / saṃsāravyavahārotthaṃ nāśāviṣayavaiśasam //
column2: I can rather suffer myself to be put under the jaws of death with his rows of teeth like saws, but cannot bear the dreadly pains of worldly cares and anxieties.

column1: idaṃ nāstīdamastīti vyavahārāñjanabhramaḥ / dhunotīdaṃ calaṃ ceto rajorāśimivānilaḥ //
column2: It is a gloomy error in this world to think that I have this and have not the other; it serves to toss about our minds as a gust of wind disperses the dust of the earth.

column1: tṛṣṇātantulavaprotaṃ jīvasaṃcayamauktikam / cidacchāṅgatayā nityaṃ vikasaccittanāyakam //
column2: It is the thread of avarice that links together all living beings like a chaplet of pearls; the mind serves to twirl about this chain, but pure consciousness sits quiet to observe its rotation.

column1: saṃsārahāramaratiḥ kālavyālavibhūṣaṇam / troṭayāmyahamakrūraṃ vāgurāmiva kesarī //
column2: I who am devoid of desires, would like to break this ornamental chain of worldliness, hanging about me as a deadly serpent, in the same manner, as a lion breaks asunder the net.

column1: nīhāraṃ hṛdayāṭavyāṃ manastimiramāśu me / kena vijñānadīpena bhindhi tattvavidāṃvara //
column2: Do you now, O most learned sage, scatter the mist which has overspread the forest of my heart, and the darkness which has overcast my mind, by the light of true knowledge.

column1: vidyanta eveha na te mahātman durādhayo na kṣayamāpnuvanti / ye saṅgamenottamamānasānāṃ niśātamāṃsīva niśākareṇa //
column2: There are no anxieties, O sage! which cannot be put to an end by the society of good minded men; the darkness of night can be well removed by moon-beams.

column1: āyurvāyuvighaṭṭitābhrapaṭalīlambāmbuvadbhaṅguraṃ bhogā meghavitānamadhyavilasatsaudāminīcañcalāḥ / lolāyauvanalālanājalarayaścetyākalayya drutaṃ mudraivādya dṛḍhārpitā nanu mayā citte ciraṃ śāntaye //
column2: Life is as fickle as a drop of water pending on a mass of clouds blown away by the winds. Our enjoyments are as unsteady as the lightning that flickers in the midst of clouds. The pleasures of youth are as slippery as water. With these reflections in my mind, I have subdued them all under the province of peace and tranquility.

column1: śrīrāma uvāca / evamabhyutthitānarthaśatasaṃkaṭakoṭare / jagadālokya nirmagnaṃ mano mananakardame //
column2: Seeing the world thus ingulphed amidst the abyss of hundreds of rising dangers and difficulties, my mind is immerged in the mire of anxieties.

column1: mano me bhramatīvedaṃ saṃbhramaścopajāyate / gātrāṇi parikampante patrāṇīva jarattaroḥ //
column2: My mind is wandering everywhere and I am struck with fear at every thing; my limbs are shaking with fear like the leaves of a withered tree.

column1: anāptottamasaṃtoṣadhairyotsaṅgākulā matiḥ / śūnyāspadā bibhetīha bālevālpabaleśvarā //
column2: My mind is bewildered by impatience for its want of true contentment, just as a young woman is afraid in a desert for want of the company of her strong handed husband.

column1: vikalpebhyo luṭhantyetāścāntaḥkaraṇavṛttayaḥ / śvabhrebhya iva sāraṅgāstucchālambaviḍambitāḥ //
column2: The thoughts of my mind are entangled in my desire for worldly enjoyments, as stags are caught in the pit strewn with grass over it.

column1: avivekāspadā bhraṣṭāḥ kaṣṭe rūḍhā na satpade / andhakūpamivāpannā varākāścakṣurādayaḥ //
column2: The senses of an unreasonable man, ever run astray to the wrong and never turn to the right way; so the eyes of a blind man lead him but to fall into the pit.

column1: nāvasthitimupāyāti na ca yāti yathepsitam / cintā jīveśvarāyattā kānteva priyasadmani //
column2: Human thoughts are linked to the animal soul as consorts to their lords. They can neither sit idle nor ramble at liberty, but must remain as wives under the control of their husbands.
